description.p: NewsAgent is a USENET Newsreader written completely in Java. It was originally my final year project at University, but I later released it as open source and have been working on it on and off for two years.

While developing NewsAgent, I had some vague general feeling that keeping stuff which might possibly come in useful for other projects in the future separate from the NewsAgent source code would be a good idea. This general code is DJU (the Dubh Java Utilities).
DJU contains a number of useful classes for internationalization, and funky UI widgets using Swing. The code is really due for a big tidyup any time soon.

Sun didn't announce JavaMail until well after I had finished the first version of NewsAgent. When JavaMail came along, it seemed like a good idea to try to migrate the hyper dodgy networking code in NewsAgent into a nice generic NNTP provider for JavaMail. This took a little longer than I expected, though :)
I'm completely addicted to strategy games of any kind. But in particular, I've been playing Civilization in various forms since it first came out on the Atari ST many years ago.

FreeCIV is an open source effort to write a replica of Civilization II. Unfortunately it's in C, and I don't really like C much. ..name goes here.. wrote a Java version, and I'm currently maintaining it...

It can be a bit of a pain to build all these projects using disparate build systems. Javac is great, but it's just a compiler. To get cool automated build systems running or distribute scripts that build your project with the code can sometimes involve writing makefiles or batch/ shell scripts.

Someone pointed me in the direction of the Apache Jakarta Ant project, just as I was really getting into XML properly. This neatly solved most of my problems. The really nice thing was, I could solve all the other problems, because the authors of Ant made it really easy to hook into. Hence, Dubh Dev Tools are a bunch of "Task"s for Ant, as well as some other useful stuff for building the projects on this site.

EWatcher is an attempt to define a Java framework for push technology. My original idea was that I'd like to have a ticker-tape-esque application running on my desktop, which was capable of receiving events from a number of sources (e.g. email with a certain subject / sender, updates to web pages, clock events, file changes on the network etc.) and displaying these prioritized in the ticker.

Something I'm doing at work involves WebDAV, so I did a little research into it. Then in a furious few hours coding, I wrote a Java client API for accessing WebDAV resources in a convenient way. I did this at home, rather than at work, so it's all open source, and I'll probably develop it further.
